comments.commentBody: Yes, and how much has that rescue cost the taxpayers? Is the Navy going to spend $1000s looking for me if I am driving on bald tires?! There is a reason why I  pay for insurance. It is called "responsibility"! it sometimes, but not always, goes with being an adult.

didn't you notice that the guy's brother criticized him and didn't send them off on their journey?  He knows them better than any of us... so you should take that into account before posting foolish comments.
Children of this age will have absolutely no memory of this trip. None.

"Done properly, it's quite safe." Sure, if a 1-year-old comes down with a fever 900 miles off the coast of Mexico, there's no danger in that. And, of course, "neither of the problems they had had anything to do with the age of the child." Quite so, I see no reason to think that a baby might be more fragile or likely to become ill in such conditions, or that she might have had more trouble sleeping than someone who understands what is going on.

You and your wife, as adults, *chose* to take the risks of your 4-year voyage. Putting toddlers in a situation where, obviously, things were dangerous enough to require the intervention of the Navy, the Coast Guard, and the National Guard is something else entirely.

There's an awful lot of ignorance on display here. First, the question of the danger of sailing the oceans. It is natural to magnify the danger of the unknown, and since we are land-based mammals, it seems terribly unnatural and dangerous to ever be out-of-sight of land. But the fact is that sailing around the world in a 36-foot boat is quite safe, as long as you choose the right time of year to cross each ocean. My wife and I spent 4 years circumnavigating in a 36-foot boat, and it was safer than a lot of things we've experienced on dry land. Before we left, friends and family came to say 'goodbye,' and the expressions on their faces made clear that they were seeing us for the last time. For a couple of them it was, as they died while we were gone. Done properly, it's quite safe. Another thing, neither of the problems they had had anything to do with the age of the child. The mother could have been the one with a rash, or the father. The steering problem had nothing to do with the fact that there were two small children aboard. The fact is that it is just a case of a family with a couple of problems quite unrelated to the hysteric rants posted here. There are many, many boats out there with young children aboard, and the parents are giving their children experiences that most people can't even imagine. Would I want to circumnavigate with young children? No, I don't have the patience.
No, no, poor people are nuts; rich people are eccentric.
HELLO.  They did not "win".  They were RESCUED.  Otherwise they would all be DEAD.

Virtually nobody immigrated to America in 36-foot boats, except maybe St. Brendan the Navigator and the Vikings, and none of them are left to tell about it.  The trans-Atlantic passage, as an experienced navigator knows, is a great deal shorter than a Mexico-New Zealand one.  What were these people thinking.

Ms. Wells, I suggest you pick up and read a history text or two, because families who made arduous trips across the ocean didn't do it for thrills, nor did they make the trip in 35-foot sailboats.

And for most of us, when we see children placed in harms way by their parents or seeing these type of actions applauded by others like you, the word "Darwinian" does not come to mind, but another word altogether, which we call "depravity."

I would be willing to bet that most who make disparaging remarks here are "Helicopter parents." Who never let their kids do anything outside their purview that is not completely supervised and organized by some adult. How far we have come in just a few generations. With the prevailing wringing of hands going on, one tends to forget that just over a hundred years ago, whole families made treks across the ocean or continent taking life threatening risks to get where they were going. If a child died, social services were not contacted because there were none. The Darwinian law regarding survival of the fittest as applied to humans is rarely tested anymore. I would suggest that the Kaufman's not only tested it, but won.
Just because they are all bad does not make it ok to do worse things!
I see a couple willing to risk a family for a book or TV deal.

To EconProf and Sarah,

It is a far cry from those whose lifestyle in retirement can be sustained entirely on funds from Social Security (with COLAs that decrease year after year and inflation increases that are continually defined away) and the 1% (or the .01% to whom Prof Krugman refers). It is also a far cry from those who lived in their earning years in the Middle Class in high-cost-of-living areas (though obviously relatively less so). EconProf apparently moved far away from loved ones in their high-cost-of-living-area in the NE or West Coast to FL where there is no income tax and other provisions to keep the cost-of-living lower. How is Skype working for you?

But to countless Middle Class workers who toiled for decades and saved to maintain their moderate lifestyle (which could not be sustained by Social Security alone) and also to stay close to hold and know their grandchildren in those high-cost-of-living areas - those savings are/were ravaged by inflation. Even at an annual 4% inflation rate (the new ideal target?!) savings would be devalued by half in 18 years (between the time one is 50 and 68 years old)! People were/would be forced to significantly reduce their standard of living, skip the birthday presents for the grandchildren and perhaps even lose their homes and move away despite their cherished dreams to stay close.

But apparently you both feel they don't know how good they had/have it!

For shame!

But the folks who settled the American West accepted that their children (not to mention themselves) might not survive such a journey and made it anyway. These folks, instead of just accepting their fate like the great American settlers before them, insisted on a happy, spare-no-expense, ending.
But, highly fortunate, due to their lack of skill and experience, that no one died.  Their emergency plan, isn't one you take on a sailboat when you cross an ocean.
I figure they'll take up sky diving.

Well, as the sailing expedition to New Zealand didn't work out, the parents are likely planning a safe land-based outing - like scaling Mt Everest with the kids in tow. Granted, Thor Heyerdahl did make it across the Pacific in a balsa wood raft but he had five other adults and a significant amount of drinking water and tinned rations with him. Whatever boating licenses the Kaufmans have should be revoked immediately and not reissued.

I'm just grateful I had the parents I had, content with the simple pleasures - dinner together every night, reading, telling stories, fresh air, laughter. Come to think of it we rarely vacationed anywhere. I enjoyed a very happy childhood and never even went on a boat!
What an amazing run!  Kevin Ollie = Coach of the Year!  Now go, UConn women!

Somehow I think we have to call into question someone who lives in the middle of a desert and claims that his three children have been sailors from the day they were "born."

Also, just to inject a sense of adult realism in this discussion, most people place a high value on life, which means that no rescuer or infant should ever have his/her life be placed at risk in the high sea due to the juvenile antics of self-centered adults.

And by the way Mr. O'Hanlon, despite what you make think, in the real world there is not any way to explain away "risk" to a toddler.
Excellent comment. Unfortunately, there are many here too stupid to hear what you are saying. But we, the sailors, understand.

Nonsense.  There are all kinds of risk--and we should judiciously choose these risks for ourselves if we like that sort of thing.  Very young children don't have a say in it.  You want to build character?  Teach them the violin and have them stand on the stage of Carnegie Recital Hall and play for an audience.  That's scary enough and the worst that can happen is a memory slip.

As a guy who has taken his kids offshore on my very seaworthy sailboat properly prepared for voyaging, I can only say to the utterly outraged people calling these parents unfit - and demanding they make reparations:

They went for it.

Glad all of you stayed home. My kids, 25, 23 and 18 have sailed bluewater, been to different countries and have graduated with honors - Patrick and Katie from college, Hannah graduating high school at 16 and will graduate college at 20. All well employed, well adjusted kids with hard core real life experience and sailors since they were born. Sailors. In open, wild ocean. Alive.

I know why this family made the decision. Yes, this didn't turn out so great. They are homeless, as their boat was their home. These people will rebound because that's what they do. Thanks to the rescuers. Great work.

This is why we have rescuers.

It's easy to excoriate them from your den, isn't it?

Risk is the place you go if you actually want to live.

Nice to see a legitimate college basketball program win the NCAA Title Game.  Their players were in College longer then the One and Outs at Kentucky and they played with more maturity. Kentucky's operates on the basis of: One &  Out.  Come to Kentucky and you will play the first year and then you can go to the NBA and make millions. We will get your thru the first semester with sham courses to insure your eligibility and the second semester doesn't make a difference because you will have already completed the NCAA Tournament and have completed your One & Out college basketball careen. We will recruit other One and Outs since you are gone and we have openings on our roster.  Our University is really not an institute of higher learning.  We are an institution of  basketball.

What is wrong with color & race blind recruitment based solely upon merit?

To be globally competitive, we need to educate our best and brightest.

How is this a "Times Pick"?

So the parent should reimburse the tax payers for the rescue, but the tax payers should now be on the hook for raising the kids? What?!?!
Stay home. It's where you belong. Leave life to people who want to grab it.
Many of those settlers and their families did not survive the experience.  However, crossing America by foot or by wagon is nowhere near as risky as trying to sail the Pacific.

Pop culture has never been my strong suit. Native culture is more my nature, and I am far more apt to express an anachronistic exclamation (from somewhere in the deep recesses of my quirky memory) on the order of, " My stars and garters!" and has much more of the desired than any reference to any of the catch-phrases from Laugh-In.

Time passes.

You have chosen poor examples. First, global warming and GMO are issues that affect everyone but mostly within large populations - like US wide. California crop shortages would affect the US most. Nuclear is much closer to the size of a large city or small country. If a nuclear reactor melts down, a large area around it becomes inhabitable, but the country is not likely to become refugees.

Vaccines are quite different. If you have an autistic child, you have an autistic child for life, and oops; you're on your own. I'm not disputing the science and have vaccinated my children because of the evidence. But try to last one hour walking in the parents' shoes of an autistic child and you'll feel something much different than fear of teenagers getting free birth control or refusing trans-vaginal ultrasounds. The hyper debates led by the GOP over ACA are so absurd that people leave the country just to have a life.

Conservatives are more worried about forcing their values upon others, or having other's values forced upon them. Liberals seem more concerned with quality of lives of the entire population - even those who are too young or too disabled to vote.
I agree with you.  Sadly, too many people have to think twice before calling an ambulance.

The rescued paying the rescue costs seems to be a popular idea in this comments section.  The problem with that is that you then give people in danger an incentive to not call for help.  "We're gonna have to pay tens of thousands of dollars for a rescue.  We're not about to die, let's wait and see if we can get out of this."  Leads to people getting into deeper trouble.  People die.  The eventual rescue likely will be more dangerous for rescuers.  This is why you normally don't have to pay for your own rescue.  It is good policy.
Yeah, but if Mom and Dad had been struck down with illness, I doubt the six month old could have operated the satellite phone to call the coast guard.

As a former merchant seaman who spent 4 years circumnavigating in a 36-foot boat, I have to say that you're missing an important distinction between a pleasure craft and any other type of vessel, A ship, be it a freighter, tanker, passenger ship, or military vessel must go where it has to go when it has to go, whatever the season. A pleasure craft can sit in port for months waiting for the best time to cross the next stretch of ocean, And that makes all the difference in the world. We spent 7 months in Panama waiting on the seasons; did you ever have the luxury of doing that?
Perfectly articulated and makes equally perfect logic.
I think you meant 'understand' and not 'things'.

AND what is really NOT stupid by the right wingers - that they sometimes understand a lot of 'things' much better - which troubles average people in their daily lifes - like the rise of prices -(and thus the fear of inflation) - or the burden of private -(and thus 'public') - debt - AND there - the much more (realistic? - scientific?) sophisticated outlook of us Liberals - turns into a type of stupidity - which has the selfdefeating potential to even beat the stupidity of the right...
